items.question: AC.L1-B.1.I - Authorized Access Control
Do you have an Access Control Policy?

answers.text: Yes
No

extension.valueString: Enter notes or supporting evidence, if any

items.question: Notes / Evidence
items.codingInstructions: Provide details, explanations, or supporting documentation for your responses including links to drives or repositories where evidence is stored.
items.value: Documented Access Control Policy outlining user access management, roles, and permissions; version-controlled and approved by management.

items.question: Have you limited system access to only approved people, devices, and tools? What is the current status?

answers.text: Fully implemented – Only authorized employees, devices, and apps can log in.
Partially implemented – Some access is restricted, but gaps remain.
Not implemented – Anyone with the link or device can get in without checks.
Not applicable – No systems in scope hold sensitive contract data.

value.text: Fully implemented – Only authorized employees, devices, and apps can log in.

extension.valueString: Enter notes or supporting evidence, if any

items.question: Notes / Evidence
items.codingInstructions: Provide details, explanations, or supporting documentation for your responses including links to drives or repositories where evidence is stored.
items.value: Access is restricted to authorized users, devices, and tools through role-based access controls and authentication mechanisms. Regular audits ensure compliance.

items.codingInstructions: Access Control Policy is a written, approved document that explains who is allowed to use company systems, what devices can connect, and what access they have.

items.question: Access Control Policy Elements
Does your documented access control policy address these items?

answers.text: Purpose, scope, roles, and responsibilities
Management commitment
Coordination among organizational entities
Compliance requirements

items.codingInstructions: Access Control Policy is a written, approved document that explains who is allowed to use company systems, what devices can connect, and what access they have.

extension.valueString: Enter notes or supporting evidence, if any

items.question: Notes / Evidence
items.codingInstructions: Provide details, explanations, or supporting documentation for your responses including links to drives or repositories where evidence is stored.
items.value: The Access Control Policy covers user account management, least privilege, role-based access, authentication requirements, and periodic access reviews.

items.codingInstructions:
Access Control Policy Elements defines the official "rulebook" for managing a user's access rights throughout their time with the company. It covers the entire lifecycle of access, from start to finish.

•   Defining Permissions (Who & What): Sets clear rules for who is allowed to access what data. For example, a salesperson can see customer records, but not HR files.
•   Granting Access (How it's given): The formal process for giving a user new permissions, which typically requires approval from their manager.
•   Reviewing Access (How it's checked): The process for regularly checking user permissions to ensure they are still necessary for their current job role.
•   Revoking Access (How it's removed): The process for promptly and completely removing a user's permissions when they leave the company or change jobs.

If you require assistance at any point, please utilize the “Ask AI” feature or contact a member of the Opsfolio CaaS team for expert support.

items.question: User Account Registry
How many accounts are currently in your systems?

codeList.display: How many accounts are currently in your systems?

items.codingInstructions: Account means any login that can access your company’s systems — whether it belongs to an employee, a former employee, or even a software tool. Tracking the total number of accounts helps ensure only the right people and tools have access.

items.question: Active user accounts:
items.codingInstructions: These are the logins for people currently working in your company who can access your systems. Each employee should have their own unique account.

items.question: Inactive/disabled user accounts:
items.codingInstructions: Inactive Accounts are logins that no longer work — for example, when an employee leaves or changes roles. They should be turned off quickly so old accounts don’t become a back door.

items.question: Service accounts:
items.codingInstructions: Service Accounts are special logins used by software or automated tools, not people. For example, a program that runs nightly backups may need its own account. They still need to be tracked and secured.

items.question: Shared accounts:
items.codingInstructions: Shared Accounts are logins with passwords that multiple people use. They are risky because you can’t tell who did what. Best practice is for everyone to have their own account instead of sharing.

Maintain a detailed and up-to-date record of all user accounts, including their access levels and status

If you require assistance at any point, please utilize the “Ask AI” feature or contact a member of the Opsfolio CaaS team for expert support.

items.question: Principle of Least Privilege Implementation
The ‘least privilege’ rule means staff should have only the level of system access their role requires (and no more). Where in your systems do you apply this rule?

answers.text: Fully implemented across all systems
Partially implemented
Not implemented

items.value: Applied to servers, databases, applications, network devices, and cloud resources; enforced through role-based access controls and periodic access reviews.

items.codingInstructions:
Grant users and systems only the minimum access necessary to perform their tasks.

Our HR system is connected, so access changes automatically when people join or leave.
We regularly review who has access and confirm it’s still correct.

items.question: AC.L1-B.1.II - Transaction & Function Control
What is the status of least privilege implementation (making sure employees only have access to the specific actions their role requires, for example, read vs. edit vs. approve)?

answers.text: Fully implemented – access is role-based and regularly reviewed.
Partially implemented – some roles limited, others still too broad.
Not implemented – all users have broad access.
Not applicable – no sensitive transactions in scope.

value.text: Fully implemented – access is role-based and regularly reviewed.

extension.valueString: Enter notes or supporting evidence, if any

items.question: Notes / Evidence
items.codingInstructions: Provide details, explanations, or supporting documentation for your responses including links to drives or repositories where evidence is stored.
items.value: Role-based access controls enforce least privilege across systems, ensuring employees have only the permissions necessary for their job functions; regularly reviewed and adjusted as needed.

items.question: Transaction Control Implementation
How do you limit employees to only the system actions their job requires?

answers.text: By job role (e.g., managers vs. staff have different access).
By type of action (e.g., can read data but not edit or delete it).
By application (e.g., only certain people can use a given tool).
By time (e.g., access only during work hours).
By location (e.g., access only from the office or approved networks).

value.text: By job role (e.g., managers vs. staff have different access).

extension.valueString: Enter notes or supporting evidence, if any

items.question: Notes / Evidence
items.codingInstructions: Provide details, explanations, or supporting documentation for your responses including links to drives or repositories where evidence is stored.
items.value: Each role is assigned specific permissions (e.g., read, edit, approve) based on job function; access is granted through a controlled approval process and periodically reviewed.

items.codingInstructions:
Implement controls to monitor and regulate transactions, ensuring only authorized actions are performed within systems and applications.

items.codingInstructions:
Limit system functions and capabilities based on user roles to ensure individuals can only perform actions necessary for their job responsibilities.

It’s not enough to control who can log in — you also need to control what they can do once inside. Each person should only be able to carry out the tasks their role requires. For example, reading vs editing invoices, viewing vs deleting customer data.

items.question: AC.L1-B.1.III - External Connections
What is the status of your controls over outside connections (internet, cloud tools, personal devices)?

answers.text: Fully implemented – Only approved external systems can connect; all activity is monitored.
Partially implemented – Some external connections are controlled, but gaps remain.
Not implemented – Any system or device can connect without restriction.
Not applicable – No external systems connect to the environment in scope.

value.text: Fully implemented – Only approved external systems can connect; all activity is monitored.

extension.valueString: Enter notes or supporting evidence, if any

items.question: Notes / Evidence
items.codingInstructions: Provide details, explanations, or supporting documentation for your responses including links to drives or repositories where evidence is stored.
items.value: External connections are restricted via firewalls, VPNs, and approved cloud services; personal devices follow a BYOD policy with security controls; network activity is monitored for unauthorized access.

Vendor/supplier systems – e.g., ERP integrations, supplier ordering platforms.
Government systems and portals – e.g., DoD contractor portals, SAM.gov, PIEE.
Personal devices (BYOD) – e.g., employees’ personal laptops, phones, or tablets.
Remote access systems – e.g., VPN, Citrix, Microsoft RDP.
No external connections – We keep all systems completely internal.

items.question: Connection Verification Methods
How do you check that outside systems and devices are safe before they connect to your network?

answers.text: We use digital certificates and PKI to prove identity.
We require VPN logins with authentication before allowing access.
We set firewall rules or restrict by IP address so only approved connections get through.
We use signed agreements with partners/vendors that spell out security requirements.
We continuously monitor and log external connections to spot suspicious activity.

value.text: We use digital certificates and PKI to prove identity.
We require VPN logins with authentication before allowing access.

items.value: Devices are scanned for malware, must comply with endpoint security policies, and are authenticated via VPN or MDM; external systems are vetted and only allowed through secure connections.

items.codingInstructions:
External System Authentication requires confirming that an outside system or device is really what it claims to be and meets your security standards before allowing it to connect to your network. Examples include requiring a secure login, using VPN or certificates, or checking that the device is company-approved.

External connections are any links between your company’s systems and outside systems — like the public internet, cloud services, vendor platforms, or even employees’ personal laptops and phones. These need to be controlled so sensitive contract data isn’t exposed.

items.question: AC.L1-B.1.IV - Control Public Information
What's the status of your process to make sure sensitive contract information (FCI) isn’t accidentally posted on your website, social media, or other public systems?

answers.text: Fully implemented – We have a written approval process, only authorized staff can post, and we review/remove public content regularly.
Partially implemented – Some controls are in place (e.g., only certain staff can post), but no formal review or monitoring.
Not implemented – Anyone can post content publicly without checks, and there is no process for review.

items.codingInstructions: Federal Contract Information (FCI) is any information your company gets from the U.S. government under a contract that isn’t meant for the public. For example, it could be contract details, project schedules, or technical requirements. It does not include information the government makes public (like what you see on official websites).

value.text: Fully implemented – We have a written approval process, only authorized staff can post, and we review/remove public content regularly.

extension.valueString: Enter notes or supporting evidence, if any

items.question: Notes / Evidence
items.codingInstructions: Provide details, explanations, or supporting documentation for your responses including links to drives or repositories where evidence is stored.
items.value: Policies and procedures prevent posting FCI to public systems; employees are trained on handling sensitive information; content is reviewed before publication to ensure compliance.
